SafetyInspectionBy: Colorado Springs Fire Department HazMat Team

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This executive summary provides a brief overview of the Risk Management Program (RMP) and the associated policies at the McCullough Water Treatment Plant (McCullough WTP), one of several facilities owned and operated by the Colorado Springs Utilities.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Colorado Springs Utilities has determined that this facility is required to comply with the RMP Program 2.  Colorado Springs Utlities believes that it is important to provide a safe workplace to its employees and minimize the impact of its operations on the surrounding community and the environment.  Accordingly, Colorado Springs Utilities has developed proactive safety and environmental programs, which are reliant upon active employee participation and management leadership and support.  This same proactive philosophy was employed in the development and implementation of the McCullough WTP RMP for the chlorine system.

The RMP prevention program is arguably the most important element of the rule.  Its program elements require the active participation of facility employees and management in conducting activities aimed at preventing accidental releases of regulated chemicals.  If prevention activities could be completely successful, there would be no need for emergency response activities, since no releases would occur.  Accordingly, a well-developed and properly-implemented prevention program will lower the possibility of an accidental release and minimize the consequences of a release should one occur.

Colorado Springs Utilities takes an active role in preventing accidental releases at all of its facilities by ensuring that its employees are well-informed regarding the hazards associated with the regulated processes (e.g., chlorine at the McCullough WTP) and actively participated in a comprehensive hazard review.  The system employees are properly trained in the safe operation of the covered processes and the safe handling of treatment chemicals.  They ar

e aided in this work by complete, understandable system operating procedures.

Colorado Springs Utilities management understands its duty to provide a safe working environment and to take measures to prevent accidents that may have an effect on the surrounding community.  This understanding is reflected in procedures described and referenced in the McCullough WTP RMP procedures and policies.

As for emergency response, Colorado Springs Utilities has established and maintains emerganey procedures.  These are reviewed with employees on a periodic basis and revised to accommodate changes in staffing when they occur.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
The McCullough WTP is located at 660 West Monument Creek Road on the Air Force Academy property in El Paso County, Colorado.  The facility treats surface water through a series of physical and chemical treatment operations including pre- and post-chlorination to provide potable drinking water to 200,000 to 300,000 residents in the Colorado Springs area.  Up to 75 million gallons of water (MGD) are currently treated daily prior to discharge into the water distribution system. 

The McCullough WTP utilizes chlorine as a disinfecting agent in the treatment of drinking water.  The facility is regulated under Program 2 of the RMP rule due to the volume of chlorine stored and used at the facility.  

Prevention Steps for Chlorine
The prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps are described in detail in the McCullough WTP RMP manual.  The prevention program includes the following elements:
? Safety information, which includes information pertaining to the hazards of chlorine in the process, process technology, and process equipment
? Hazard review, which includes a systematic evaluation (by an employee team) of:  the hazards of the chlorine process, identification of previous process incidents, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failure of the engineering and administrative controls,

facility siting, human factors, and possible safety and health effects of failure of controls
? Operating procedures, which include steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions
? Training for each McCullough WTP employee involved in operating the chlorine system
? Computerized maintenance program including schedules and job plans to maintain the on-going integrity of the chlorine process equipment
? Compliance audits at least every three years from 1999 to evaluate McCullough WTP RMP compliance
? Incident investigation, to be conducted and documented for each incident that resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a catastrophic release of chlorine from the McCullough WTP

In addition to these elements, the chlorine storage facility at McCullough WTP is equipped with a chemical scrubber.  In the event of a release of chlorine in the storage room, the normal ventilation system shuts down and the chlorine-contaminated air is sent to the scrubber for neutralization.  The scrubber is maintained and tested on a regular basis to ensure proper operation during a chlorine release event.

Accident History
Within the five-year period prior to the submittal of this RMP, there were no accidental releases of chlorine meeting the requirements of 40 CFR 68.42.

Emergency Response Program
This facility is included in the Colorado Springs LEPC Emergency Response Program.  In addition, McCullough WTP has established and maintains emergency procedures, which includes an evacuation and notification plan.  The goals of the established procedures are to protect onsite employees from the hazardous effects of chemical releases and to minimize the effects of releases on the general public.  The procedures are routinely reviewed and updated to reflect personnel and regulatory changes.  Colorado Springs Utilities works closely with the Colorado Springs LEPC and other local industries and agencies to coordin

ate local response activities.

Planned Changes for Improved Safety
Ideas for changes to improve safety are actively sought from employees.  Employee meetings that focus on safety issues are held regularly at the McCullough WTP.  Employees are encouraged and trained to recognize hazards and to present ideas to eliminate them or to minimize the potential consequences of those hazards.
